# How-to Reminders

::: callout-tip
Maybe put things you often google here.
:::

### Add Citations

-   Add [citation from Zotero](https://rstudio.github.io/visual-markdown-editing/citations.html) in Visual Mode: `@` or `⇧⌘ F8`
-   The full text reference gets copied into the file specified in the `bibliography:` YAML option for the current file. If this option isn't specified it defaults to `references.bib`, and makes the file if it doens't already exist.

#### Add page number to in-line citation

Use markdown syntax of `[@author pp. 5]` -- [Quarto Docs](https://quarto.org/docs/authoring/footnotes-and-citations.html#sec-citations)

#### Cite tables/figures reproduced or adapted from other papers

-   Get permission from copyright holder
-   Follow the following format as given by this [library guide](https://web.archive.org/web/20171019090302/http://library.nmu.edu/guides/userguides/apacitingtables.htm)

<!-- -->

    Material adapted from a journal article. Note format is different from References.

    Note. Descriptive note. Adapted [or Reprinted] from “Title of Article,” by F. M. Author and C. D. Author, year, Title of

    Journal, volume, p. xx. Copyright year by the Name of Copyright Holder. Adapted with permission.

    Example:

    Note. Values are percentages. Reprinted from “Hope and Social Support as Resilience Factors Against Psychological

    Distress of Mothers Who Care for Children With Chronic Physical Conditions,” by T. V. Horton and J. L. Wallander,

    2001, Rehabilitation Psychology, 46, p. 387. Copyright 2001 by the Educational Publishing Foundation. Adapted with

    permission.

-   See also:
    -   [academia.stackexchange](https://academia.stackexchange.com/questions/3100/id-like-to-use-a-figure-from-a-paper-whats-the-best-way-to-do-this) question thread for specific guidance, including for IEEE.
    -   [APA style guidelines on Scribbd](https://www.scribbr.com/apa-examples/citing-tables-figures/)

## Quarto in Rstudio Visual Mode

### Edit during meetings/discussions

-   Git commit pre-meetings
-   Use visual mode to add notes
-   Turn on `Sync Editor` option in Viewer pane to show any page navigated to in the Viewer
-   Make sure `canonical` writer option is turned on to ensure Visual and Source mode files don't conflict (see [Visual Mode docs](https://rstudio.github.io/visual-markdown-editing/options.html#file-options))

## Quarto Markdown

Uses a combination of RStudio's visual mode [^how-to-guide-1], and Quarto/Markdown [^how-to-guide-2]. Required snooping the source code for the Quarto website, and adapting R Markdown tutorials.

[^how-to-guide-1]: For more features see [RStudio Visual Markdown Website](https://rstudio.github.io/visual-markdown-editing/)

[^how-to-guide-2]: Somewhat specific to the Quarto Website format. For more features see [Quarto Website](https://quarto.org/)

### Add Emojis

-   Type slack-style `:smile:` in [Visual Mode](https://rstudio.github.io/visual-markdown-editing/content.html#tight-lists)
-   use `html: from: markdown+emoji` to access shortcodes

### Embed images

-   `CMD-V` to paste image from clipboard in Visual Mode; note that image will be duplicated into `_site/`
-   drag & drop [^how-to-guide-3]
-   Borrow tricks from RMarkdown (http://zevross.com/blog/2017/06/19/tips-and-tricks-for-working-with-images-and-figures-in-r-markdown-documents/)

[^how-to-guide-3]: See *Exploring RStudio's Visual Markdown Editor* [Blog Post](https://www.rstudio.com/blog/exploring-rstudio-visual-markdown-editor/)

### Share YAML options

-   put them in `_quarto.yml` for project wide options
-   add them into `folder/_metadata.yml` for files inside a given `folder/`

### Add Page and Section links

-   Use this format to add [links between "pages"]((https://quarto.org/docs/websites/#linking)) to specific #sections --

``` markdown
[topic](lit_review.qmd#topic)
```

### Add Inline Footnotes

-   More on footnotes in [Quarto Authoring Guide](https://quarto.org/docs/authoring/footnotes-and-citations.html#footnotes)

``` markdown
Here is an inline note.^[Inlines notes are easier to write,
since you don't have to pick an identifier and move down to
type the note.]
```

### Text formatting

-   Use [Visual Mode editing shortcuts](https://rstudio.github.io/visual-markdown-editing/content.html#tight-lists) like `⌘B`, `⌘I`
-   See [Markdown Basics](https://quarto.org/docs/authoring/markdown-basics.html#text-formatting)
-   Use spans for additional styling

+-----------------------------------+-------------------------------+
| Markdown Syntax                   | Output                        |
+===================================+===============================+
|     *italics* and **bold**        | *italics* and **bold**        |
+-----------------------------------+-------------------------------+
|     superscript^2^ / subscript~2~ | superscript^2^ / subscript~2~ |
+-----------------------------------+-------------------------------+
|     ~~strikethrough~~             | ~~strikethrough~~             |
+-----------------------------------+-------------------------------+
|     `verbatim code`               | `verbatim code`               |
+-----------------------------------+-------------------------------+

#### Colour text

-   Add span `[]` around text and specify css style inside `{}` -- [A Quarto tip a Day](https://mine-cetinkaya-rundel.github.io/quarto-tip-a-day/posts/11-spans/)

    For example, `[red]{style="color: red;"}`, renders as: [red]{style="color: red;"}

### Set Editor Mode Defaults

-   Go into **RStudio -\> Preferences -\> R Markdown -\> Visual**
-   Make [tight lists](https://rstudio.github.io/visual-markdown-editing/content.html#tight-lists) default

### Share content between pages

-   Use Includes shortcode syntax given in [Quarto Guide](https://quarto.org/docs/authoring/includes.html#overview): {{{< include _content.qmd >}}}
-   Always use underscore (`_`) prefix for included files so they are not treated as standalone

### Install and Update Quarto

Handled via [Quarto homebrew cask](https://formulae.brew.sh/cask/quarto#default)

``` bash
# first time
brew install --cask quarto
# update
brew upgrade --cask quarto
```

### Add Listing to a page

1.  Add the following basic listing options to the YAML header of the page you want the listing to appear on:

``` yaml
---
listing:
  id: article-notes
  contents: lit_review/**
  type: table
---
```

Make sure the content you want to list is in the specified folder (`lit_review/`). If you omit this option the listing will display all files in the document directory, except for the current document.

2.  Add a div element in your document and specify the `id` to locate the listing in your document

``` markdown
## Keywords

-   keyword
-   another keyword

## Article Notes

::: {#article-notes}
:::
```

3.  Modify the display of the listing by specifying additional options after the basic listing options above.

``` yaml
---
listing:
  id: article-notes
  contents: lit_review/**
  type: table
  # --- extra options ---
  fields: [title, subtitle, author, date]
  field-display-names: 
    subtitle: "Citation"
  sort: "author"
  date-format: "YYYY"
---
```

The content you are listing should contain the listing fields in their YAML headers. For example, a document in `lit_review/**` might have a header like:

``` yaml
---
title: "blockCV: An r package for generating spatially or environmentally separated folds for k-fold cross-validation of species distribution models"
author: "Valavi, Roozbeh, Jane Elith, José J. Lahoz-Monfort, and Gurutzeta Guillera-Arroita."
date: "2019"
subtitle: "@valavi2019"
---
```

Which produces an listing like:

![](images/Screen%20Shot%202022-05-14%20at%2010.19.03%20pm.png)

Notice that the field `subtitle: "@valavi2019"` is parsed into an inline citation when displayed on the page with the listing. This requires the specification of the `bibliography:` option in the YAML header, which can be inherited from a project level YAML file or in the file itself.

### Add verbatim inline r code

New `verbatim` engine in [knitr v1.37](https://github.com/yihui/knitr/blob/master/NEWS.md#changes-in-knitr-version-137) allows for the following syntax:

````` md
````{{verbatim, lang="markdown"}}

We can output arbitrary content verbatim.

```{{r}}
1 + 1
```

The content can contain inline code like
78.5398163, too.
````
`````

and from files

```` md
```{{verbatim, file="test.rmd"}}
```
````

also chunk option:

``` md
#| file: test.rmd
```

Showing a verbatim inline code chunk was.. tricky. See [blog post](https://yihui.org/en/2017/11/knitr-verbatim-code-chunk/) by Yihui Xie for why this works.

``` markdown
This will show a verbatim inline R expression `` `r
1+1` `` in the output.
```

This will show a verbatim inline R expression `` 2 `` in the output.

### Navigation and site structure

-   Add `navbar:` and `sidebar:` elements to `_quarto.yml`. Also use `section:` element to group navigation items.
-   See [Quarto Docs](https://quarto.org/docs/websites/website-navigation.html), and [YAML file for Quarto Docs on GitHub](https://github.com/quarto-dev/quarto-web/blob/main/_quarto.yml)
-   Try to use a `title/index.qmd` folder structure when making listings.
    -   It's a little bit annoying when editing multiple `index.qmd` files, but at least it all has a consistent structure -- also same structure as Hugo website.

    -   Good for keeping pasted images together with the files that actually use them.
